required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: An Epidemiological Study on Winter Sports Injury in Chinese Population
clinical_study.official_title: An Epidemiological Study on Winter Sports Injury in Chinese Population

brief_summary.textblock: The aims of the study are to describe the injury patterns among recreational skiers and snowboarders in China and to provide primary data to guide the reconstruction of regional healthcare facilities to deal with the increasing number of participants in snow sports.

detailed_description.textblock: A retrospective study was performed in Ski Resorts in Chongli, China. 5000-10000 injured skiers and snowboarders will be recruited. Data of all injury patients in the resort clinic will be collected. Patients' information, including sex, age, equipment, skill level and injured body part, will be analysed.

primary_outcome.description: Equipment was classified into skis and snow-boards. Special equipment such as cross-country skis and skiboards is rare in China and has not been recorded in the present study.
Patients were classified according to self-reported years of participation in skiing and snowboarding: beginner (first season), medium (1-5 years), advanced (5-10 years) and expert (≥10 years).
Date of injury was divided into weekdays and weekends/holidays according to the Chinese government holiday arrangement.

We summarised causes of injury into two types according to the subjective description of the scene of injury: not involving others, defined as falling or crashing without any body contact with others; and involving others, defined as crashing that involves two or more people.
Slope difficulty was categorised into beginner trail, medium trail and advanced trail according to the official data of slope inclination angle.
Injured body parts were categorised into the following four anatomical body regions: (1) head/cervical, (2) torso, (3) upper extremity and (4) lower extremity.

arm_group.description: Patients were classified according to self-reported years of participation in skiing and snowboarding: beginner (first season), medium (1-5 years), advanced (5-10 years) and expert (≥10 years). Date of injury was divided into weekdays and weekends/ holidays according to the Chinese government holiday arrangement.

study_pop.textblock: Data for this retrospective study were collected from the resort clinic in Chongli during ski season. Chongli is a destination ski resort in Northern China which has various terrains and has the largest number of annual visits.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Skiing and snowboarding injuries
Exclusion Criteria:
- Skiing and snowboarding visitors without injuries
